data.text: Contents
Introduction
To provide a mechanism for appropriately qualified staff to refer patients for radiological examinations.
To provide supporting guidance related to the scope of the role and the consequential education and training requirements.
Background
The justification for non-medical health care professionals referring to radiology must be that patient care will be improved by the practice, and reflect current accepted practices.

The NHS Plan included many initiatives to modernise the way in which care is delivered. This includes broadening the scope of practice for many health care professionals and referring patients for diagnostic imaging is just one example. One of the 10 key roles for nurses includes referral for diagnostic investigations. This has not been restricted to nursing, allied health professionals (AHPs) are also developing their roles, and as such, co-ordination of these roles and relevant education is required.

Healthcare Professionals may be in positions where their expanding roles require them to provide a comprehensive service for patients and will require access to imaging to meet this need. It is often appropriate that a person other than a doctor refers for radiological examinations, this may be to provide an efficient service, or because the person responsible for initial and subsequent patient management is another health professional.

Appropriate initial and continuing education must underpin all role development and training programmes. A level of responsibility for the education of staff lies with the clinician from whom the role is delegated and the radiology department, which will take responsibility for the areas of development related to radiation protection
Scope
This policy covers staff employed by the Trust and staff employed by General Practitioners contracted by the CCG.
All non-medical professions registered with the nursing and midwifery council or health and care professions council are included within the scope of this policy.
All referrals for examinations performed by the radiology department are included within this policy, both those involving the use of ionising radiation and those not, such as Ultrasound or MRI.

The Specialty Scope of Practice Agreement (Appendix 2) is designed to identify for the Trust the degree to which appropriately trained non-medical health professionals will refer patients for examinations.
Associated policies and procedures
This policy should be read in conjunction with The Standard Operation Policy ‘Referrers Procedure for requesting Medical exposures', V.1.1. – see Appendix

Services and practices which implement referral for radiology by non-medical staff should provide documentation to establish the rationale for this development in the form of clinical guidelines (refer to section 10). This policy should therefore be read in conjunction with these specific clinical guidelines.
Please refer to the site specific MRI Operational Policy and Pregnancy policies.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
All Parties

6.1.1 All parties must be certain that the member of staff is suitably qualified, experienced and competent to carry out the responsibilities delegated to them. In addition the following roles and responsibilities apply.
Primary Care Trusts
6.2.1  Staff will be supported to develop their role through the Trusts clinical governance and continuing professional development arrangements.
Radiology Service Managers
6.3.1 To maintain a site based list of authorised referrers.
6.3.2 To approve the delegation and referral agreements.

6.3.3 To provide an educational programme covering Ionising Radiation (Medical Exposure) Regulations (IR(ME)R 2017) by approved Radiation Protection Advisors or Radiation Protection Supervisors, where the referrer wishes to refer for ionising radiation procedures.
6.3.4 To provide an education programme covering MRI safety, where the referrer wishes to refer for MRI examinations.
Clinicians

6.4.1 When delegating a role, the clinician retains full clinical and managerial responsibility for the patient. The clinician shares responsibility for proper performance of the task not only with the delegated member of staff but also that person's employer.

6.4.2 Responsibility for the education of staff in relation to their role in the clinical areas lies with either the clinician from whom the role is delegated for staff employed by a GP practice or from the appropriate director responsible for the service provision for staff employed by the Trust.
Service Managers/Practice Managers
6.5.1 Identification of any current practice covered by this policy.
6.5.2 Maintain a list of approved referrers within the radiology site shared drive.
6.5.3 Ensure changes or additions to the referrers list are submitted to the radiology department, prior to referrals commencing.

6.5.4 Ensure appropriate IR(ME)R education and training is undertaken by non-medical referrers and ensure the non-medical referrers are aware that this training needs to be refreshed every three years
The MSE Radiology Departments
6.6.1 Each MSE radiology department will take responsibility for specific areas of development indicated in section 10.6.
6.6.2 To ensure regular review of the quality of referrals is undertaken during the justification process of radiology referrals
Referrer
6.7.1 To ensure that initial and continuing education and training is undertaken to ensure competence in their role.
6.7.2 Referrers should read and act upon the results of every investigation requested by the team.

6.7.3 The clinical teams should have a robust mechanism for handover of urgent imaging reports, and for handover of pending urgent imaging study requests, to ensure that all significant imaging findings are acted upon by the clinical team in a timely manner, regardless of which clinical staff are actually on duty.
6.7.4 Referrers should have a clear understanding of the MSE agreed fail-safe alert policy within the Trust and act upon ALL reports in a timely manner.
Referral process
General Principles

7.1.1 It is the responsibility of the referrer to provide sufficient clinical information to enable justification and clarify expectations of the examination. Examinations must be justified under IR(ME)R for referrals involving ionising radiation (in line with iRefer – Making the best use of clinical radiology – Royal College of Radiologists, UKAS Guidelines for ultrasound referrals and MHRA guidelines for MRI referrals).
7.1.2 The radiology department (Radiographer, Sonographer or Radiologist) will refuse any referrals that are considered inappropriate.

7.1.3 All referrals should be completed electronically unless under exceptional circumstances. All referrals written referrals must be legible and must indicate clearly the name and role of the referrer e.g. Nurse Practitioner, Cardiac Nurse and department/GP practice.

7.1.4 The referrer must complete all of the fields on the request form. It is inappropriate for one health professional to complete part of the form and another to sign it since the Radiology Department must be sure that the person completing the request holds relevant clinical assessment skills and authorisation to be able to justify the decision.

7.1.5 If any referrer is in doubt as to whether an investigation is required, or which examination is best, they should discuss the case with an appropriate medical practitioner, Radiologist or Radiographer, prior to referral.
7.1.6 Notice should be taken of previous relevant examinations in order not to expose a patient to ionising radiation unnecessarily.
7.1.7 All referrals must be completed in line with the IR(ME)R Schedule 2 documentation and include:
3 points of identification
Modality required
Region for examination
Side of examination (if applicable)
Appropriate clinical information with a clinical question in order to justify the procedure
The referrer's contact details (and signature if a paper request)
Date of referral.
If the referral is for a planned scan (e.g. 3 months post treatment) then this should be clearly stated in the clinical details of the referral.
The most appropriate examination will be undertaken in line with the radiology standard protocols.

7.1.8 It is the referrer's responsibility to ensure the patient does not have any devices (such as a pacemaker) that may contraindicate the procedure taking place. If any implants or devices have been identified, documented evidence of the make, model and serial number, position in the patient and the date of implant should be provided. Please note there are many devices that are incompatible with MRI scanning. Advice should be sought prior to completing a referral if it is unclear whether the particular patient is suitable for the radiology modality.
Categories of referral

7.2.1 There are currently two categories of referral for imaging, with an acknowledgement of the different levels of responsibility for patient care, however both carry the same level of responsibility for the referral process. The categories are:
Assessment of patient and referral for imaging based on clinical signs e.g. Nurse Practitioner.

Referral under protocol i.e. under direction from doctor in notes/specific pathway. Where a referral is made under a direct pathway, this should be documented as such within the clinical details section of the referral form along with the individual patient's clinical details in order to justify the procedure.

7.2.2 It is recognised that there are different requirements for education and training relevant to the clinical role and these will have to be met prior to commencing referrals. Further details are provided in section 10.
Referrals that cannot be justified
7.3.1 When insufficient information is given to justify an examination the referrer will be contacted using the supplied contact details. These would include:-
When the referral is being vetted by the clinical team within Radiology and they are unable to determine from the clinical details that the examination is justified.
Minimum data set and referrer's signature is not present on the request form (if not utilising the electronic referral system).
Inpatient requests that are still required after discharge should be clearly documented in the clinical details.
7.3.2 If the referral is not justified, the reason for cancellation will be entered on the radiology RIS system. Site cancellation processes will then be followed.
Consent

It is the responsibility of the referrer to ensure that informed consent is obtained for the procedure they are requesting. This includes, where appropriate, discussing the risk versus the benefit of an examination.
This does not absolve the radiographer/sonographer from their responsibility with regard to patient consent.
Interpretation

IR(ME)R states that all radiology reports should be formally reported. This clinical report may be issued by a Radiologist, Sonographer or Reporting Radiographer dependent on the procedure. In some cases, there may be a delegated authority agreement for Non-Radiology staff to record an evaluation in the patient's medical records (refer to site specific IR(ME)R procedures / SOPs).
Training requirements
Specific education relevant to their own area of practice must be undertaken by all staff in order to support their role development.

All MSE non-medical referrers must complete training in the relevant electronic requesting software so that imaging requests can be electronically generated. Non- medical referrers working in the community which currently use paper request forms i.e. GP surgeries may continue to use paper request forms until their department converts to electronic requests.
Paper requests from other areas are only accepted in exceptional circumstances.

All MSE non-medical referrers must complete radiation awareness training. This training may only be delivered by Radiation Protection Supervisors or Radiation Protection Advisors. These can be booked by contacting:-
For Broomfield natalie.hockaday@nhs.net For Southend lee.shoesmith1@nhs.net For Basildon hugh.kemp@nhs.net
Radiation Protection
10.4.1 This training is relevant only for those referring for imaging procedures involving ionising radiation and will encompass the following:
Potential hazards in irradiating patients and an understanding of the associated regulations.
Contraindication to referral for imaging and the risk of unnecessary exposure to ionising radiation
Radiation protection of high risk groups
The role of the Referrer, Operator and Practitioner.
General Education
10.5.1 All other referrers, regardless of the modality of referral, should be aware of the following:
Indications for referral for imaging.
The mechanism and importance of Audit.
Referral guidelines and completion of referral forms.
Communication with the patient of the need (or not) for radiological examination and associated issues.
Consent.
Clinical Education
10.6.1 This must be appropriate to the category of referral, and should be agreed within the delegating clinical director/GP and documented in the individual referrer agreement.
10.6.2 The education may be delivered locally or as part of a recognised post registration programme, but must encompass all of the details of the role and responsibilities.
Development of new speciality scopes of practice

Where new roles are developed within the Trust, new scopes of practice should be developed to ensure the proposal has the full support of the Trust and that issue of patient safety and staff development have been considered. This would also apply to those scopes already in place that need extending to encompass a wider selection of examinations.
The following should be considered within the guidelines:
Benefit to the patient of the initiative;

Number of patients expected to be referred by non-medical staff per month under this initiative. This should also indicate whether this replaces referrals from the delegating clinician or whether this is a new initiative / increase in referrals
Specific examinations to be referred including specific inclusion or exclusion for age of patients;
Identify which categories of patients are to be referred. (This should include the expectations of the service e.g. orthopaedic clinic);
Staff involved in:
Proposed commencement date;
Who is responsible for the initial interpretation of the resultant images? (This includes recording the evaluation in the clinical records).
The guidelines must identify the education and training to be completed by referrers.
Radiology referral agreement

A Radiology Referral Agreement must be completed for all non-medical referral protocols. This may affect individuals or groups of individuals dependent on the clinical area. It is comprised of 2 parts: a Speciality Scope of Practice and an Individual Referral Agreement. The pathway to enable the agreement to be reached can be found in Appendix 1- Radiology Referral Agreement Pathway.
Speciality Scope of Practice (refer to Appendix 2)

12.2.1 The speciality scope of practice is an agreement between the radiology service and the delegating clinician/GP, and should be completed with reference to the points in Section 11, using the Speciality Scope of Practice form in Appendix C. There should only be one Speciality agreement per role within the Trust. For example, Stroke Clinical Nurse Specialist or Emergency Department Emergency Nurse Practitioner.

12.2.2 The agreement will identify the scope of practice i.e. the professionals covered under the scope of Practice, department, the examination(s) wishing to be requested and under what circumstances, exclusions, benefit to the patient of the scheme and initial reporting arrangements for images.

12.2.3 Once completed, new MSE Speciality Scope of Practice forms should be returned to the Radiology Governance Lead. These will then be reviewed by the deputy general managers and the clinical lead radiologists.
12.2.4 The delegating clinician/GP must sign the Speciality Scope of Practice form and will be responsible for delegating the referral process.
Individual Referrer Agreement (Refer to Appendix 3)

12.3.1 Confirmation must be given that the individual is working to approved clinical guidelines and has received supervised clinical training from the delegating clinician. A copy of the clinical scope of practice they wish to refer under, must be appended to the individual referrer agreement.

12.3.2 Confirmation must be given that the individual has received the IR(ME)R training (and MRI safety training as applicable) delivered either within the Trust or other certificated equivalent training on Radiation Awareness, if appropriate to the referral.

12.3.3 Responsibility as a referrer cannot be transferred between individuals and any new appointments must follow the guidelines in place for the speciality and an Individual Referrer Agreement must be completed and submitted to the radiology governance lead (at Broomfield) or the Lead Radiation protection supervisor (at Basildon & Southend).

12.3.4 The Individual Referrer Agreement must be completed electronically, signed and sent as an attachment via e-mail to the radiology governance lead (at Broomfield) or the Lead Radiation protection supervisor (at Basildon & Southend). This will then be reviewed by a Clinical Lead who will authorise or decline the application. This agreement is a local agreement and is non-transferable. All non-medical referrers working within this organisation must have a local agreement in place.
12.3.5 Any agreement which is declined by the Radiology Department will be returned to the applicant with a full explanation as to how this decision was made.
12.3.6 The Individual Referrer Agreements will be stored electronically on the Radiology relevant radiology drive.
12.3.7 The Radiology Department can terminate referral rights at any time, either in whole or for any named individual for any persistent abuse of the agreement.
Risk management
In the event that there is a query with the request or individuals operate outside of their agreed Scope of Practice, there will be an initial consultation with the individual concerned.
In the event of a disagreement, the radiographer has the right to refuse a request and ask for a medical opinion. Any such incidents will be documented and investigated via MSE Datix Web system.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Radiology Clinical Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Radiology guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Radiology Clinical Governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 1: Referrals procedure for requesting medical exposures
Purpose
The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that all persons making referrals for medical exposures are entitled to do so by Mid and South Essex (MSE) Hospitals.
Referrals will be accepted from the following Medical groups:-
All permanent registered medical practitioners employed by the Trust
All locum registered medical practitioners employed by the Trust
All Mid and South Essex GP's registered with the General Medical Council
All Dental Practitioners registered with the General Dental Council
All medical practitioners, registered with the GMC referring patients under the ‘Choose
and Book' system.
The list of approved referrers can be found on the radiology site radiology drive.
Referrals will also be accepted from registered the Health And Care Professionals Council (HCPCs) and other approved referrers
The IRMER schedule 2 documentation relating to referral guidelines must be followed
and approved.
Once a new speciality scope of practice along with the individual referral agreement is
approved, the named referrer is added to the approved list on the appropriate site radiology drive. The original copy is kept with the site radiology governance lead / lead RPS as applicable.
The referrer is then given access to the relevant IT requesting systems.
Referrals will be made within the current Royal College of Radiology guidelines and also within any local guidelines.
Each specialist group will refer only to their agreed protocols. Duties of the referrer are: -
To supply the correct details for patient identification, using a 3 point ID check.
To supply sufficient medical data to enable the practitioner to justify the exposure,
including checking previous examination history.
To assess the pregnancy status of child bearing potential patients between the age of
In the case of other non-medical referrers - They must follow the local
procedures/protocols as agreed by Radiation Protection Committee and the Referrers Clinical Director.
Contact details of the referrer must be provided on the request.

All referrers not using the recognised secure computer systems (Hospital internal or Choose and Book) must be able to provide a sample signature if requested by the Trust. Appendix 2: Speciality scope of practice
